titlestmt.titleproper: National Committee on United States-China Relations records, RG 4, Accession 4
A Guide to the National Committee on United States-China Relations records, RG 4, Accession 4 FA1186

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-09-21 00:35:32 -0400.

did.unittitle: National Committee on United States-China Relations records, RG 4, Accession 4

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: National Committee on United States-China Relations, Inc.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

When requesting to view audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact an RAC archivist for further instruction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: RG 4 contains records of Exchanges to and from China, mainly from the early 1970s to the mid-1980s, and includes records of the Ping Pong Diplomacy visit of the Chinese table tennis team in 1972. The Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues series includes records of seminars held for the regional press in the 1960s - early 1970s, and early explorations of exchanges with China. Significant materials in other series include Program files relating to educational outreach, such as BAYCEP, the Bay Area China Education Project; and Art and Archaeology files relating to the archaeological exhibit that toured the U. S. from China in 1974-1975.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The National Committee on United States – China Relations (NCUSCR) was established in 1966 as a nonprofit educational organization with a mission to encourage mutual understanding and dialogue between citizens of the United States and China.

The National Committee came into being through the cooperative efforts of scholars and civic, religious, and business leaders who, at a time of mutual hostility between the two countries, sought to stimulate public discussion about China and the United States' relations with it by sponsoring conferences, seminars, publications, and other education and outreach programs. In 1972, the National Committee sponsored the Chinese table tennis team's historic U. S. visit. This round of "Ping Pong Diplomacy," which followed closely on Richard Nixon's visit to China in February 1972, helped pave the way for later exchanges and, eventually, for the normalization of relations with China in 1979. Building on these cultural exchanges, the National Committee came to be a primary organizer of professional and policy exchanges between the two countries (and including Hong Kong and Taiwan), in the areas of foreign affairs and international relations, economic development, governance and legal affairs, education, mass media, environmental and global issues, etc. As its role in exchanges became more prominent, the National Committee turned over some of its educational programs to the Asia Society in the late 1970s, but it continues its educational role through public education events and ongoing outreach.
Funding for the National Committee comes from the United States government (especially the Department of State), corporations, and foundations, as well as from its individual membership.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records of the National Committee on United States – China Relations are divided into ten record groups, which reflect the order in which the records were received (but which are otherwise an artificial distinction). The records are sorted intellectually into series, which carry over through all record groups, but they have received little or no physical rearrangement. RG 4 of the NCUSCR records is arranged into eight series: 2 - Exchanges - General; 3 - Exchanges to China; 4 - Exchanges from China; 5 - Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues; 7 - Art and Archaeology; 8 - Programs, Projects, and Proposals; 9 - Ping Pong Diplomacy; and 10 - Development.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The National Committee on United States-China Relations donated its records to the Rockefeller Archive Center by deed of gift dated March 27, 2015.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Special formats separated from the body of the collection are stored in the following containers:

did.unittitle: Exchanges - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Exchanges – General series in RG 4 mainly documents the establishment of a multi-year cooperative program between the U. S. and China in the area of urban planning and design. The program began with the visit of the Urban Design Study Team in the fall of 1981 (the records of this visit are found in Series 4, Exchanges from China).

did.unittitle: Exchanges to China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Exchanges to China series in RG 4 documents exchanges mainly from the 1970s to the early 1980s. The exchanges included cultural organizations such as the Philadelphia Orchestra in 1973, the Boston Symphony Orchestra in 1979, and a dance delegation in 1980; sports delegations (Swimming, Track and Field, Gymnastics, Volleyball, and Basketball, 1973-1979); educators (including college presidents, local and state education officials, science educators, and the National Institute of Education), 1973-1981; political representatives and officials (Congressional staff, young politicians, mayors, and governors), 1975-1979, 1983; plus delegations of City Planners (1979) and on World Affairs (1975). The National Committee also sent delegations of its Board members from 1972-1982 (6 visits).

The Exchanges to China series also includes files on visits to China by U. S. presidents, cabinet officers, and officials, ranging from Henry Kissinger's secret trip to China in 1971 to George W. Bush's visit in 2002. These files consist for the most part of clippings and copies of government documents; there is little or no original content.
Exchanges files are generally dated by the trip date. The dates do not reflect the exact date range of the contents.

did.unittitle: National Institute of Education Delegation - Report Drafts
National Institute of Education Delegation - Report Papers and Drafts
Exchanges from China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Exchanges from China series documents exchanges from 1973 to 1990. The range of delegation topics suggests a broad interest in these exchanges. Sports and martial arts featured in some of the early exchanges (Gymnastics, 1973; Wushu Troupe, 1974; Women's Basketball, 1975; Tennis, 1979). In 1978, the Performing Arts Company, composed of performers and artists from the Beijing Opera and the China National Ballet Troupe, toured the U. S. to great acclaim. Other delegations studied foreign language publishing and teaching (1973-1980s); education; journalism, radio and television broadcasting, and press law; government, law, justice, and foreign relations; economic planning and development. The China International Travel Service delegation traveled in 1978; a Women's Delegation in 1979; and the Chinese People's Committee for the Defence of Children visited in 1980. Other files concern Civil Engineering and Architectural Education and Urban Design delegations in 1981.
The dates listed for Exchanges files generally refer to the trip date. They do not reflect the exact date range of the contents.

did.unittitle: Writers Delegation
Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues series documents some of the National Committee's early initiatives to increase public knowledge and understanding of China. From 1967 to 1971, the NCUSCR sponsored seminars and other programs for Regional Journalists around the U.S., with an aim of improving awareness and coverage of China in the press. It also reached out to local civic and business Community Leaders for membership and support for its seminars and presentations. In 1968, the NCUSCR engaged the Norwegian journalist Harald Munthe-Kaas to travel throughout the U. S. and speak about his experiences in China. In the early to mid- 1970s, the NCUSCR, with support from the Johnson Foundation, also organized a series of round tables and conferences to explore developing relations with China and the prospects for exchanges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Art and Archaeology series contains files relating to the exhibit, Archaeological Finds of the People's Republic of China, which toured the U. S. in 1974-1975, opening at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC, and then traveling to the Nelson Gallery – Atkins Museum in Kansas City, MO, and the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco.

did.unittitle: Times Atlas of China Offer
Programs, Projects, and Proposals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Programs, Projects, and Proposals series contains files relating to the NCUSCR's Media Services program, 1971-1977, and to its Education projects – especially the Bay Area China Education Project (BAYCEP), 1973-1975, and the Project on Asian Studies in Education (PASE), 1971-1975.

The Media Services program helped organize news briefings on China and provided bibliographies and background readings for journalists and others engaging in early exchange programs – particularly for President Nixon's trip to China in 1972. The Media Services files consist primarily of memos and correspondence by Donald W. Klein, a political scientist who was hired in 1971 as program consultant for mass media.

The National Committee's educational programs gathered information on university-based resources and programs in Asian Studies and encouraged links with primary and secondary school educators through teacher workshops and the development of instructional and resource materials. The Bay Area China Education Project (BAYCEP) developed training programs and resources for teachers on Chinese culture and U.S.–China relations. The Project on Asian Studies in Education (PASE), based at the University of Michigan, formed a resource center and provided similar outreach and training for high-school and college teachers and graduate students.

Ping Pong Diplomacy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ping Pong Diplomacy files document the Chinese Table Tennis Team's historic visit to the U.S. in April 1972. The U.S. team had visited China in 1971. Traveling only a few weeks after President Nixon's trip to China, the Chinese Table Tennis Team was the first delegation to visit the U. S. from the People's Republic of China.
Records concern arrangements and planning for the visit, fundraising, press coverage, and follow-up. In 1997 participants held a twenty-fifth anniversary reunion.
